Report of the Auditor of Public Accounts STATE OF NEBRASKA OFFICE OF THE AUDITOR OK PUBLIC ACCOUNTS To His Excellency, John H. Mo \ v\ IFhere should be a change in the laws of Nebraska in relation to mblication and distribution of the annual reports of State off- Is, bureaus, departments and commissions. Large sums are used le printing and binding of reports for which little demand • which lay in the basement of the State House for years and are !y sold to the junkman for almost nothing. flmost every law passed of late years creating a commission has ed a provision that it shall make a lengthy itemized report, the to be printed and bound at the State's expense and specifies the number of copies to be issued, regardless of whether many will ing mis period, ar.d point out exact nnanciai conditions ol u • departments of our state government. In this report I am suggesting that you recommi which will, I of our state and make more effective our several tlepa I believe that the intimate acquaintai: sarily has with the conditions of which this proposed legislation places him in a position to mak 'ions along these lines that maj be of assistance to vou: Equalization of Salarii Many existing salaries were fixed years ago when the duties of th« various positions were much less and the cost of living also not so great In many other cases salaries should be adjusted a similarity in salaries in different departmei •• anc volume of work is very similar. We would suggest that an equalizatior and readjustment of salaries would be very desirable at this time. Printed State Reports:

6 Ehem or not. I would suggest that state officials required to fixed number of reports be consulted by the next legislature and » amended, cutting the number printed to the miminum that is -y and that the reports of all special commissions created in the * held to a reasonable number. Special Voucher and Warrant Blanks: We believe where any department requires a special form of voucher other than the stock General Fund and stock Cash Fund voucher now furnished by this office, or where they require a special or separate warrant book that the expense of said special blanks should be paid by the department demanding same. It is very unfair that the Auditor's office expense fund should bear this expense. In many cases special tax levies are made for these departments or their income is derived from other sources entirely than taxation and the Auditor's office is simply a clearing office to enable the records of the departments in question to be open to public inspection in conformity with the Gerdes law. Revenue Books and Blanks: An appropriation has always until the last session of the Legisla - ture been made for Revenue Books and Blanks. Article III, No. 5546, Tenth paragraph, Revised Statutes, 1913 provides "it shall be the duty of the Auditor to furnish such books, blanks, etc., as may be necessary for the use of County Clerks, Treasurers, Assessors, or other officers hav - ing duties to perform under the revenue laws which shall be sent, upon requisition of the County Commissioners to the Clerks of the proper counties for distribution to the several officers, the expense of which shall be paid out of the State Treasury." K Notwithstanding the provisions of the above statute the last legis- I failed to make the usual appropriation. In consequence we could furnish insofar as our stock of books and blanks on hand would and very few were furnished the past year. This appropriation should either be reinstated by the coming legis - lature or the above provision of the statute should be repealed. Plural Salaries and Overtime: I would suggest that where an employee is upon the regular pay - roll at a certain monthly or annual stipend that they shall not be al - lowed to draw additional salary or compensation from either their own or some other department. The statutes should be so amended as to cover this point. Appropriation for Board of Commissioners of State Institutions: I believe that a lump appropriation for the use of this Board should be given them sufficient to cover maintenance and salaries at all insti - tutions, allowing said Board to handle to best advantage. I believe this method would enable the Board to get the best results for the State and likely at the less total expenditure.

7 I would suggest that an appropriation sufficiently large be made tate Printer to purchase all office supplies and printing for all tments, boards and institutions and that everything in this line id for out of this fund and that the various funds from which ng and office supplies are not paid be diminished each their pro - nate amount. If this is done the State Printer's office should be ed to be open each business day instead of one-half time as at it. Bonds of State Employes I suggest the passage of a law to the effect that no personal bonds be accepted by the state and that the state shall pay the premiums on all official bonds and fix the maximum rate of premium that it will pay on each. There is lack of uniformity in the law in relation to the payment of surety bonds. Some Board members, one constitutional officer at least, and his deputy, and a few others have their bonds paid by the state while others are required to stand this expense. The state should either pay all or none. It should not discriminate. State Postage: I would suggest that a recommendation be made to the legislature looking toward a different manner in handling State postage. Some central station should be maintained in the building, either a branch of the Post Office or under control of some Board that would issue all post - age upon written requisition of the various department heads or Boards, keeping a complete record of same. Furnish offices, etc., for State Treasurer: Paragraph Ten, Article III, No. 5546, Revised Statutes, contains the following which is obsolete and should be repealed. "It shall be the duty of the Auditor to furnish offices for himself and State Treas - urer and all fuel, lights, books, blanks, forms, paper and stationery required for the proper discharge of the duties of their offices. Female Attendants for Prisoners. It has been the practice for several years to allow pay at the rate of $2 per day and necessary traveling expenses for female at - tendants for female prisoners sent to either the State Penitentiary, the Geneva and the Milford institutions. It is a matter of strict justice that this be allowed but we believe there is no specific authority of law for the allowance of such claims. I suggest that this class of claims be legalized by statute as a matter of ordinary justice. The Auditor's Office: It has been our intention to suggest some changes in the salaries, duties and titles of the Auditor's office force but instead will leave these matters entirely to my successor and will make estimate for appropria-

8 it r. I ' I tt 1 ' ' i ■»' i'ii>'r\ ' • r i ' i • i . i " * .\',i.im . > i . tions the same as last biennium, leaving same subject to increase or decrease according to his ideas. There is urgent need of fireproof vault storage room in basement for the safe preservation of records and files, an estimate for which I have added to appropriation requested. Examination of County Treasurers: BTie law providing for the examination of County Treasurers has of great benefit to the state. The state has not had a loss from source since the law was effective. One County Treasurer re - ' became mentally unbalanced and a small shortage discovered but will be no loss to the state. Our predecessor at the conclusion of his term of office was com - pleting examinations each 22 months. We have succeeded by the ex - treme diligence of our examiners and the help furnished them by other employees of this office in reducing the examination period to 12 months. Bnder biennial examinations our examiners orders cannot be en - by returning two years after and shortages are less liable to under the shorter period. ■We recommend that an additional examiner be employed for one - time and a proportionate appropriation for expenses be made. Old Insane Account: When we assumed the duties of this office there was due the state from various counties the sum of $96,282.88 for care of their insane previous to 1891 when the present law became effective. Why former State Auditors made no effort to collect this we are unable to say. We immediately proceeded to collect this principal and have up to Xovem - 0, 1914. collected, had levies made or promised by resolutions of the various County Boards the amount of $61,149.60. Of the balance unad - justed, $6,139.15 is represented by two suits now pending in the Supreme Court and payment of the balance of $28,944.13 will likely be arranged by the various County Boards owing same during month of December. I Five counties only refused to either pay or make a levy and against e five counties I started suit for recovery. Since starting suit two ities have made partial payment and agreed to make levy to pay balance. Another county has advised me officially that it will e levy and the three suits will be dismissed without prejudice upon payment of accrued costs. fdo not know whether the legislature has the power to authorize mediation of the interest charge but if so and it sees fit to do so the is counties will, I believe, each willingly pay the principal in full, those counties that are now resisting action in the court. I beg to advise, also, that several counties have overpaid in the total amount of a trifle over $600 and I suggest that the legislature pass an act to re-imburse each county for the amount of the overpay-

KKl'ORT <>l A I I'llnlt < >K I'l UI.M 9 Old I ndaimed Warrants There has accumulated in this office for years many unclaimed warrants, the owners of which it has been impossible to locatt gTeat many of these are in payment of old wolf bounty claims. There are now 849 warrants amounting to $3,516.60. These are simply taking up storage room in our vaults and during the biennium not a single one has been called for. If same can legally be done the legislature should take such action as necessary to cancel these anil clear our boo - these entries still .standing open. Auditor's Office Expense Owing to the increased business of the State which adds to the volume of same in the Auditor's office we may possibly have a small deficiency in our office expense fund. We cite an instance or two Bny showing increase, viz. That almost 10,000 more warrants an - are now written than under the previous administration: That sues of bonds were approved and registered and about 50 issues were rejected, making a total of Ma handled as agai biennium, or an increase of 41 tin case the law is changed ami the State Printer is required to for all printing out of his fund the Auditor's office expense fund likely be reduced for the biennium. But in case no change ? it may be necessary t< se the Aiulitoi ppro- priatic Ehe matters above mentioned are simply suggestions on my part ited to assist you somewhat in preparing your recommendations next legislature. We hope that some of them may prove of \ you. Yours respectfully, W. B. HOWARD Auditor of Public \
